Costco, the beloved wholesale retailer, announced on Wednesday that it will require identification at all registers, including self-checkout lanes, eliminating a popular shopping secret. This was a workaround for shoppers who had not paid for an annual membership, but could borrow a member's card or QR code from the Costco app to avoid the identification requirements of the regular checkout lanes. The company said that it had noticed that nonmember shoppers had been using other people’s membership cards, which are nontransferable, in the self-checkout lanes. The success of Costco’s business model relies on rigor, and the company said that it was “able to keep our prices as low as possible because our membership fees help offset our operational expenses.” The retail market has grown tighter, and the company is becoming stricter in a more difficult economic environment. The member renewal rate was around 90 percent worldwide in 2022, and revenue from membership fees totaled $4.2 billion. The company has not raised the cost of its membership since 2017, but executives indicated in a recent earnings call that the cost might increase.

  1. Costco is requiring identification at all registers, including self-checkout lanes, to eliminate a workaround for shoppers who have not paid for an annual membership.
  2. The success of Costco's business model relies on rigor and strictly monitoring entrances and exits and double checking customer receipts.
  3. A regular membership costs $60 a year, and an executive card costs $120 a year.
  4. The retail market has grown tighter, and the crackdown at Costco may be due to increasing pressures on corporate margins and the rising cost of commodities, labor and overhead for wholesalers.
  5. Costco has not raised the cost of its membership since 2017, but executives indicated in a recent earnings call that the cost might increase.

"Costco is like a guard at a castle gate, checking identification and receipts to make sure no one enters without a valid membership, and increasing security as the pressures of the retail market grow."
